title: Event Management: Legal Requirements and Sustainability
headline: This free online course outlines some of the UK legal requirements for events and how to plan sustainable events.
description: In this sustainable events management course, you will learn about the legal requirements in the United Kingdom you need to consider as an events planner. You will also see how to ensure your events are successful and sustainable enough to leave a lasting legacy. The material also examines health and safety issues as well as how to prepare for emergencies, before taking a closer look at the importance of marketing, insurance and tax.

courseDescription:
This course will guide you through health and safety issues and explains how to produce events that are compliant with British law. You will learn about the event planner's role in creating safe events and how to apply for permits. You will also discover the legal requirements for weddings and how to plan for accidents and emergencies.

Next, you will see how to set goals for events and measure success using quantifiable or soft measurements. Find out how to plan sustainable events management and discover why marketing and branding are instrumental to every business. The material goes on to explain how A/B testing can help you choose the right marketing tools and outlines why word-of-mouth marketing is so valuable.

Finally, you will discover the importance of building a website and how to use social media advertising to your advantage, before learning about your responsibilities regarding insurance and tax. As an events manager, it is vital that you are prepared for things to go wrong, and this requires knowledge and strategic planning. This sustainable events management course will help prepare you for a career in the industry and give you an advantage over the competition. So why wait? Start learning today.

Start Course Now

topics: Event Management: Legal Requirements and Sustainability Course assessment

slides:
• Learning Outcomes

  • After completing this module, you will be able to:
    • Identify the various safety policies that events planners have to watch out for.
    • Describe how to run an event safely.
    • Explain how to take care of employees and contractors.
    • Describe how to manage health and safety during the event.
    • Explain how to produce events that are compliant with UK laws and the legal requirements in other countries.
    • Outline an events planner’s role in creating safe events.
    • Explain the process of organising health and safety procedures.
    • Explain how to apply for the appropriate permits.
    • Outline the legal requirements for weddings.
    • Explain how to plan for emergencies.

  • Health & Safety

  • Health and safety isn’t just something events planners choose to focus on, it’s a legal requirement.

    When you don’t engage in health and safety, you become criminally liable for any accidents that occur. Worrying scenarios you might face include being sued, being prosecuted for negligence, and losing your reputation as an events planner.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • What do events planners have to watch out for?
  • You have a few basic health and safety obligations as an events planner. This includes:
    • Making sure your workers are insured and safe.
    • Keeping yourself safe.
    • Protecting members of the public and their belongings.
    • Taking care of any contractors you’ve hired to work at the event.

  • Managing Health and Safety Risks

  • As an events organiser, you have a duty to manage health and safety risks for the duration of the event.

    Some of your basic duties include:
    • Making sure everyone, including the staff, are aware of hazards.
    • Identifying risks and having appropriate health and safety measures in place to control them.
    • Making sure employees and those in attendance are aware of the potential safety risks threatening them.
    • Ensuring the staff are competent enough to undertake their roles safely.
    • Monitoring health and safety compliance throughout the event.
    • Reviewing health and safety arrangements throughout the event to ensure they’re still appropriate.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • It is important to remember that the nature of your health and safety management tasks will change as the event goes on. The more people arrive, the greater the need to manage them.

  • Health and Safety for Events Planners

  • As an events planner and events manager, you will be held responsible for the health and safety of the event. 

    You will be responsible for all of the practical issues involved in your event. From set up to tear down, you need to ensure that nothing in your planning is putting people at risk.

    Some of your duties as an events planner include:
    • Performing a health and safety check to control the risks and hazards.
    • Make sure that people are working together properly and that the activities complement each other.
    • Providing the relevant health and safety information to your employees.
    • Training your staff in the appropriate areas.
    • Monitoring compliance with health and safety regulations.
    • Reviewing your health and safety attempts and adjusting accordingly.

  • Acquiring a Licence in the UK

  • Here you will learn about acquiring a licence in the UK, be sure to find out what the licencing requirements are in the country you are hosting an event in.

    Licensing in the UK is guided by the Licensing Act of 2003. The act primarily deals with what is called ‘regulated entertainment.’ This includes public events like:
    • Theatre performances.
    • Film showings.
    • Indoor sports events.
    • Live music performances.
    • Dance performances.
    • Boxing or wrestling entertainment.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Most of the events that you plan will not require a licence or a permit. School functions, charity balls and corporate events can all be run without first applying for planning permission.

  • Lesson Summary

  • In this module, you learned how to plan procedures before an event. In addition, we focused on what your health and safety priorities are during an event, as well as how to make an emergency evacuation procedure.

    A health and safety policy is a document that states the procedure of an organisation and how they relate to health and safety.

    This is a very inexpensive but important thing for an events planner and the team working for them and with them. It is the responsibility of an events planner to present to their own staff an overview of health and safety risks.

    Most of the duties carried out to manage health and safety risks involve training and creating awareness to the staff and attendees of potential safety risks

    When work is coordinated on-site, staff are less likely to get in each other’s way, which means there are less health and safety risks present. As an events planner, you’re responsible for presenting your own staff with an overview of health and safety risks.

    The biggest piece of legislation that affects event planners in the UK is the 2003 Licensing Act. It covers all of the ground regarding who requires which licence for which events.

    The biggest piece of legislation that affects event planners in the UK is the 2003 Licensing Act. It covers all of the ground regarding who requires which licence for which events.

  • Learning Outcomes

  • After completing this module, you will be able to:
    • Describe how to set goals for events.
    • Explain the quantifiable measurements of an event.
    • Explain soft measurements for an event.
    • Outline the benefits of a sustainable event.
    • Discuss how you can make sure your event supports your community and the environment.
    • Identify the importance of your event’s legacy.
    • Explain the different reasons that events change.
    • Analyze different professional tools that can create better events.
    • Describe the different personal tools to create better events.
    • Explain how to implement meaningful changes in your next event.

  • Introduction

  • You have spent months planning and preparing to pull off a great event. All of the pieces come together, despite a few setbacks, and now you are ready for the big day. 

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • However, you still have one question: what constitutes a successful event?
  • In this module, you will learn about the different ways that you can measure the success of your event. Using this information is important because the more you know about what makes a great event, the more sustainable your events will be in the future.

    You will also learn how to plan a sustainable event. Sustainable events are events that focus on supporting your local community, the global community and the environment.

    When you are planning an annual event, you have a unique opportunity to leave a lasting impression. This impression can be transformed into your event’s legacy and you want it to be a good one!

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • In this module, you will learn about all of the different things that you can do to ensure that your next event is even better than the one before.

  • Sustainable Events

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • A sustainable event is an event that meets the following qualities:
    • A safe atmosphere.
    • An inclusive setting that is accessible for everyone.
    • Encourages healthy lifestyles.
    • Minimal environmental impact.
    • Uses sources responsibly.
    • Encourages the trend in sustainable behaviour.

    • Changes are a natural part of the event planning process. Change is both a positive and a negative thing. 

      Though all of the changes that you make to your event should be positive, they might feel negative when you are making them.

      For example, if there was a part of the event that you were working on that had become a pet project, it can be hard to let go of that. Even if it didn’t work at all and the data suggests that it needs to go, it can feel like a personal failure.

      Another problem with change is that it can be hard to get your team on the road to creating meaningful changes. As noted, changes that feel negative can be scary. No one wants to be uprooted even if the results might be beneficial.

      As the event manager, you need to lead your team through change so that they will be able to embrace that change.

    • The first thing that you should do when creating major changes is to eliminate rank. That may sound like it will only confuse the situation more. 

      Here is why it doesn’t:

      When you eliminate rank during a change up, you are showing that change affects you no matter who you are. Change is egalitarian and does not matter how much you make or how many people you lead. 

      It also shows that someone’s rank in a team does not bear witness to their character or their ability to do their job.

    • The next thing you should do when implementing change is to work on a project basis. Do not try to overwhelm your team by making dozens of changes at once. 

      You should also not expect only one person to be able to make all these changes. Thus, you should identify the appropriate team member for the project so that they can make the changes on their own. This will also help shift your team from being focused on leadership to being focused on performance.

      When you are working on projects, be sure to make the team member’s talent to the task at hand. Even if someone else worked on the original project, be sure to choose the person who is most capable of taking the project to where you need it go to.

      To be able to do this, you should explore the competencies of your team. The competencies of your team members will have changed over time, just as yours have. Remember to stay on top of the new skills that your team has developed so that you can best use them for the next event.

Thus, you should identify the appropriate team member for the project so that they can make the changes on their own. This will also help shift your team from being focused on leadership to being focused on performance.

      When you are working on projects, be sure to make the team member’s talent to the task at hand. Even if someone else worked on the original project, be sure to choose the person who is most capable of taking the project to where you need it go to.

      To be able to do this, you should explore the competencies of your team. The competencies of your team members will have changed over time, just as yours have. Remember to stay on top of the new skills that your team has developed so that you can best use them for the next event.

  • Lesson Summary

  • Setting goals should be done before planning for an event. These goals help in keeping the planning process on track. Goals are also used to measure the success of an event, therefore they should be concrete and realistic as possible.

    Goals and costs of your event can be measured by comparing with hard quantifiable measurements from the event such as leads gathered from the event, those that convert into sales and the revenue from the sales.

    An event can also be measured using soft measurements, these metrics are not necessarily numbers. Instead, they offer more feedback about whether people enjoyed the event and how engaged they were.Sustainable events are events that focus on supporting your local community, the global community and the environment.

    Sustainable events should meet the following qualities: a safe atmosphere, an inclusive setting that is accessible for everyone, encourages healthy lifestyles, minimal environmental impact, uses sources responsibly and encourages the trend in sustainable behaviour.

    When you are planning an annual event, you have a unique opportunity to leave a lasting impression. This impression should be a good one since it can be transformed into your event’s legacy.

  • Building a Website for Your Business

  • The question for many first time business owners in today’s market is this: do you even need a website anymore? The answer to this question is an emphatic ‘yes.’ Everyone needs a website today. 

    You need this website for several reasons:
    • It provides you with credibility.
    • It is an easy way for customers to find more information about you.
    • It provides an easy way to contact you.
    • It’s a gateway for referrals.
    • It is the basis of your internet marketing plan.
  • Very few businesses can succeed these days without a website. You cannot rely on traditional marketing or social media alone. 

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • You should think of your website as the centre of your marketing campaign. Everything else should radiate from around it.

  • Insurance, Equipment & Health and Safety

  • When you are first setting up your business, you will need to look at the following to ensure you adhere to health and safety guidelines and good business practices.
    • Insurance.
    • Business Equipment.
    • Tax and VAT.

  • Lesson Summary

  • When you start your business, you need to market and advertise it so as to make it profitable and sustainable.Marketing impacts how many potential customers see you, and how they see you. It is both psychological and business-oriented. Having great marketing skills is essential for running a profitable business.

    Advertising is essential, regardless of how big your budget is. There are plenty of options to choose from whether you have a little or a lot of money to devote to your marketing plan.

    The first rule of marketing is to create a brand for yourself. Your brand sets you apart from other businesses. It also affects how people experience your business.

    Creating a brand for your business takes time and dedication. Most importantly, you need to create a sense of continuity for your business.

    Word of mouth is the most powerful advertising tool in any industry. This is because people will trust their friends more than they will trust the advertisements that you paid for.

    Some of the most effective marketing and advertising tools include the use of websites, Local Business Directories, social media and Google Adwords.

    Advertising is essential, regardless of how big your budget is. There are plenty of options to choose from whether you have a little or a lot of money to devote to your marketing plan.

    The first rule of marketing is to create a brand for yourself. Your brand sets you apart from other businesses. It also affects how people experience your business.

    Creating a brand for your business takes time and dedication. Most importantly, you need to create a sense of continuity for your business.

    Word of mouth is the most powerful advertising tool in any industry. This is because people will trust their friends more than they will trust the advertisements that you paid for.

    Some of the most effective marketing and advertising tools include the use of websites, Local Business Directories, social media and Google Adwords.
